feed.title: NewsTracker: mexico
feed.subtitle: This is a news tracking demo

entry.title: New Mexico working to modernize voting system
entry.summary: New Mexico is embarking on the final phase of an effort to modernize the state's election management and voter registration system, but officials say some changes won't be fully implemented until after the 2016 general election.

entry.title: Donald Trump says some of his comments about Mexico distorted
entry.summary:
After days of outrage, Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump said on Monday that some of his criticism of Mexico has been distorted but stuck to his stance that many illegal immigrants coming across the Mexican border are criminals.

Trump said the recent killing of a woman in San Francisco by a illegal immigrant from Mexico with a criminal record proves him right.

entry.title: Donald Trump says some of his comments about Mexico distorted
entry.summary:
However, he said, the United States has become "a dumping ground for Mexico" with illegal border-crossers smuggling illicit drugs and carrying "tremendous infectious disease."

"This is merely one of thousands of similar incidents throughout the United States. In other words, the worst elements in Mexico are being pushed into the United States by the Mexican government," he said.

entry.title: Mexico rescues 12 Cubans from makeshift raft
entry.summary: MEXICO CITY (AP) - The Mexican Navy says it has rescued 12 Cuban men who were found aboard a makeshift raft off the coast of the Yucatan Peninsula.

entry.title: Police: Beltran Leyva Cartel Boss Arrested in Mexico City
entry.summary:
Martin Villegas Navarrete, 38, was captured without a shot being fired while celebrating his birthday in the Roma Norte district of Mexico's capital, Mexico's Federal Police said in its official twitter account.

He allegedly used warehouses in Mexico City's main wholesale market as cover for his drug trafficking activities.

entry.title: Police: Beltran Leyva cartel boss arrested in Mexico City
entry.summary:
With the takedown of the Beltran Leyva leadership, the cartel splintered into smaller gangs that operated in central and southern Mexico, including the states of Morelos and Guerrero south of Mexico City.

Authorities in Mexico say Villegas controlled the Guerrero-Morelos-Mexico City corridor.

entry.title: Mexico City proposes regulations for Uber
entry.summary: "Regulation that allows us to continue to provide service that is quality, safe and efficient," said Luis de Uriarte, Uber spokesman for Mexico and Central America.

entry.title: Mexico City proposes regulations for Uber
entry.summary: The Organized Taxi Drivers of Mexico City have pushed the city to regulate or ban Uber, saying it's unfair that its drivers avoid costly licensing and inspections that taxis must undergo to operate.

entry.title: 7-year-old wounded in firefight in Mexico dies
'Cartel Land' shows good and bad of vigilantes in Mexico, US
entry.summary: The film opens on July 2, 2015 in Mexico, a day later in New York and and later in other U.S. cities.

entry.title: 'Cartel Land' shows good and bad of vigilantes in Mexico, US
entry.summary: "The central question I'm trying to answer in this film is whether it's just for citizens to take the law into their own hands," Heineman said at a recent news conference in Mexico City.

entry.title: 'Cartel Land' shows good and bad of vigilantes in Mexico, US
entry.summary:
MEXICO CITY (AP) - The documentary "Cartel Land" opens with chilling night scenes of large-scale methamphetamine cooking in rural Mexico.

The film, with the Academy Award-winning director Kathryn Bigelow as executive producer, opens in Mexico on Thursday, in New York on Friday and later in other U.S. cities.

entry.title: NYC reviewing Trump contracts after remarks
entry.summary: During the event, Trump said immigrants from Mexico are "bringing drugs, they're bringing crime, they're rapists, and some, I assume, are good people."

entry.title: Mexico: 7 Police Charged With Torture in Army Slaying Case
entry.summary: Authorities in Mexico on Wednesday formally accused seven state police officers of torturing three women who survived a confrontation a year ago in which soldiers allegedly killed at least a dozen suspected gang members after they surrendered.

entry.title: Mexico: 7 police charged with torture in army slaying case
entry.summary:
Four of the police officers have been detained and a judge is expected to issue an arrest warrant for the other three, according to a statement from the Attorney General's Office in Mexico State, where the killings took place.

Three women who survived came forward to say that agents of the Mexico State prosecutor's office had tortured them to support the army's version.

Before Wednesday, no charges had been filed against any of the detectives or prosecutor's agents accused of trying to cover up the case, although the Mexico State prosecutor had said about 20 were under investigation.

entry.title: New Mexico governor denounces Trump's comments
entry.summary: Last year, she won re-election in blue-leaning New Mexico, the state with the largest number of Hispanic residents, by a wide margin.

entry.title: New Mexico governor denounces Trump's comments
entry.summary:
New Mexico Gov. Susana Martinez denounced GOP presidential hopeful Donald Trump's recent remarks about Mexican immigrants and called his comments "horrible."

In addition, Martinez has gone on a number of trade missions to Mexico and has been pushing for more infrastructure at the booming border town of Santa Teresa.

entry.title: 1 Year After Mexico Army Slayings, Calls for Justice Mount
entry.summary: None has been charged, although about 20 are under investigation, the Mexico State prosecutors' office said.

entry.title: 1 year after Mexico army slayings, calls for justice mount
entry.summary: One year after soldiers executed as many as 15 suspects at a grain warehouse in southern Mexico, many say justice has still not been done.

entry.title: Mexico won't send contestant to Miss Universe
entry.summary:
Jones was Miss Universe 1991 and runs the Mexico competition.

She lauded Mexico's media giant Televisa for deciding not to air the pageant in announcing that Mexico would not participate.

entry.title: Mexico won't send contestant to Miss Universe
entry.summary: MEXICO CITY (AP) - Mexico's national beauty pageant director confirms the country won't send a contestant to the Miss Universe contest because of insulting remarks by Donald Trump, an owner of the pageant.

entry.title: Smart cycle jacket could save lives on Mexico City's roads
entry.summary:
Mexico City's bumper-to-bumper traffic is a problem for the sprawling capital city's cyclists.

Damian Real, a physics students, came up with the design for the smart bike jacket with his partner Riberto Rivas, a maths major, at Mexico's National Autonomous University.

entry.title: Mexico's deportations of Central American migrants up 79 percent in first 4 months of 2015
entry.summary: Data from Mexico's National Immigration Institute say that 51,565 immigrants from Guatemala, Honduras and El Salvador were deported between January and April, up from 28,736, during that period in 2014.

entry.title: Escapees planned to go to Mexico
Mexico's Televisa drops Miss Universe after Trump remarks
entry.summary: MEXICO CITY (AP) - Mexican media giant Televisa says it will no longer broadcast the Miss Universe Pageant or engage any other communication project with Donald Trump.

entry.title: Prison Escapee David Sweat Says Plan Was to Go to Mexico
entry.summary: "The plan was to head to Mexico, which would have been aided by Joyce Mitchell's vehicle," Cuomo said.

entry.title: Escapees? ride to Mexico a no-show so pair tried to walk to Canada: Cuomo
entry.summary: "When Mitchell doesn't show up, the Mexico plan gets foiled, and they head north toward Canada."

entry.title: Mexico president leaves hospital after gallbladder surgery, says he's feeling 'very good'
entry.summary: MEXICO CITY - Mexican President Enrique Pena Nieto left the hospital on Sunday after undergoing surgery to remove his gallbladder.

entry.title: Mexico President Leaves Hospital After Gallbladder Surgery
Boy Scout dies in flash flood while camping in New Mexico
entry.summary:
The teen was one of eight Boy Scouts participating in a 12-day trek at the Philmont Scout Ranch when the flooding hit, New Mexico State Police spokesman Chad Pierce said.

"At Philmont we strive to provide a safe and inspiring setting for Scouts to experience the natural environment of northern New Mexico and seek to protect both Scouts and wildlife."

entry.title: Boy Scout dies in flash flood while camping in New Mexico
entry.summary: CIMARRON, N.M. (AP) - New Mexico State Police say a Boy Scout on a camping trip with his troop has died after he and three other teens were swept away in a flash flood.

entry.title: Boy Scout killed in flooding at New Mexico ranch
entry.summary:
A Boy Scout was killed when a flash flood triggered by heavy rains swept through a canyon on a New Mexico ranch where he was camping, authorities said on Sunday.

The boy was swept away in flood waters in the North Ponil Canyon, the New Mexico station said.

Some 20,000 Boy Scouts visit the 214-square-mile Philmont ranch in northern New Mexico annually for backpacking, camping and other programs, according to its website.

entry.title: Donald Trump pinata all the rage in Mexico
entry.summary:
A pinata depicting US Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump hangs outside a workshop in Reynosa, Mexico.

On Thursday, Mr Trump said he has great respect for Mexico and loves Mexicans.

Mr Trump said last week on Twitter: "I like Mexico and love the spirit of the Mexican people."

"Oscars were a great night for Mexico & why not - they are ripping off the US more than almost any other nation," Mr Trump tweeted.

entry.title: AT&T to Spend $3B on Expanding Iusacell Network in Mexico
entry.summary: AT&T spent about $4.4 billion to buy both Iusacell and the Nextel Mexico mobile system between November and January.

entry.title: AT&T to invest $3 billion in expanding newly acquired Iusacell mobile phone network in Mexico
entry.summary:
MEXICO CITY - AT&T Inc. plans to invest about $3 billion to build up its recently acquired Iusacell mobile phone network in Mexico.

Iusacell announced Thursday that the plan will extend voice and data services to cover about 100 million people in Mexico by 2018.

entry.title: Univision Cancels Miss USA Over Donald Trump's Mexico Comments
Body of ex-White House chef found in New Mexico: Reports
entry.summary: The body of a former White House chef last seen setting off for a hike alone more than a week ago near Taos, New Mexico, was found on Sunday evening, according to the New Mexico State Police.

entry.title: Mexico Deports 49 Percent More Minors in First 5 Months
entry.summary: While the wave of child and teen migrants has dropped off at the U.S. border, detentions of Central American minors are up sharply in Mexico this year.

entry.title: Mexico deports 49 percent more minors in first 5 months
entry.summary: Mexico's National Immigration Institute says detentions of Central American minors have risen 49 percent compared to the similar period last year.

entry.title: Searchers find body of missing ex-White House chef in New Mexico
entry.summary: The body of 61-year-old Walter Scheib was found Sunday night near a hiking trail in mountains in the Taos area, the New Mexico State Police said.

entry.title: Mexico's deportations of Central American migrants up 79 percent in first 4 months of 2015
entry.summary:
MEXICO CITY - Mexico deported 79 percent more people from Central America's northern triangle in the first four months of 2015 than it did during the same period a year earlier, according to government statistics.

The Inter-American Commission on Human Rights on Wednesday expressed its "concern over stepped-up actions reportedly being taken against migrant persons" that were put in place after Mexico initiated its Southern Border Plan last year under pressure from the United States.

In 2014, more than 46,000 unaccompanied minors from Central America crossed into the United States, leading the U.S. government to turn to the governments in Mexico and Central America to try to stanch the flow.

entry.title: Mexico's Deportations of Central Americans Rise Sharply
entry.summary: "Enormous numbers of Central Americans are still fleeing, but most of them are now getting caught in Mexico instead of the United States," he said.

entry.title: Soldiers Kill 6 Presumed Criminals in Northern Mexico
3 New Mexico teen boys charged with cyberattack on Enfamil baby formula website
entry.summary: ALBUQUERQUE, N.M. - Authorities say three Rio Rancho, New Mexico, teenage boys orchestrated a cyberattack on the Enfamil baby formula website, attracting the attention of the FBI and Secret Service.

entry.title: New Mexico police search mountains for missing former White House chef
entry.summary:
Authorities resumed a search by air and ground Saturday in a New Mexico mountain range for a former White House chef who has now been missing for a week.

Scheib recently moved from Florida to Taos, New Mexico, and reportedly went for a hike on 13 June in the mountains near the Taos Ski Valley.

entry.title: Tropical Storm Carlos Batters Mexico's Southwest Coast
entry.summary: Officials ordered schools closed Monday and readied shelters along Mexico's southwestern coast as Tropical Storm Carlos battered beaches with high waves and strong wind as it swirled just offshore.

entry.title: Former first lady in Mexico says she will compete for the presidency in 2018 election
entry.summary:
FILE - In this Jan. 13, 2008, file photo, Mexico's former president Felipe Calderon, right, accompanied by his wife Margarita Zabala, waves upon their arrival to a military airport in Guatemala City.

Zabala announced on Sunday, June 14, 2015, her intention to run for president of Mexico in the 2018 elections.

entry.title: Ex-first lady says she'll seek Mexico's presidency in 2018
Former first lady in Mexico says she will compete for the presidency in 2018 election
entry.summary:
MEXICO CITY - The wife of Mexico's former President Felipe Calderon says she intends to run for president in the 2018 election.

Zabala said the party needs to find "a national leader of consensus" and narrow the gap between politicians and Mexico's voters, many of whom complain about corruption in government.

entry.title: NY Gov: Escaped inmates could be close or 'in Mexico by now'
NY Gov: Escaped inmates could be close or 'in Mexico by now'
entry.summary:
Two convicted murders who used power tools to cut their way out of a prison near the Canadian border could be nearby or "in Mexico by now," New York Gov. Andrew Cuomo said Sunday.

"We don't know if they are still in the area or if they're in Mexico by now," Cuomo said in response to a question at a news conference on school aid in the New York City suburbs.

entry.title: Carlos, Briefly a Hurricane, Weakens to a Tropical Storm
entry.summary:
Sergio Pina, 41, a business risk manager from Mexico City, stood among a group of spectators watching the wild weather.

Rain accumulations of 6 inches to 10 inches were possible in southwestern Mexico, with a chance for up to 15 inches in some areas, according to the hurricane center.

entry.title: Carlos weakens off Mexico, but heavy rains and strengthening seen
entry.summary: Meanwhile on the other side of the country, a low pressure system in the Gulf of Mexico was producing showers on the coast of Guatemala, Belize, and the Yucatan peninsula, and it could become a tropical storm in the next two days, the NHC said.

entry.title: Hurricane Carlos weakens some, nearly stationary off Mexico
entry.summary: Hurricane Carlos has weakened slightly but is expected to regain punch, hovering stationary over the Pacific Ocean off Mexico.

entry.title: Fabricio Werdum shocks Cain Velasquez, Mexico City crowd at UFC 188
Kirby inspires England to 2-1 win over Mexico
entry.summary:
6 to a much-needed lead before Mexico's Fabiola Ibarra gave her team hope with a goal in stoppage time, but there was little time for an equaliser.

England, 1-0-1, will finish its Group F stage against Colombia in Montreal, while Mexico, 0-1-1, will play France in Ottawa.

entry.title: Forecasters Issue Hurricane Warning as Carlos to Strengthen off Southwest Mexico Late Sunday
entry.summary: Forecasters issue hurricane warning as Carlos to strengthen off southwest Mexico late Sunday.

entry.title: England beats Mexico 2-0 at Women's World Cup
entry.summary:
Fabiola Ibarra scored in stoppage time for Mexico.

Mexico, last in its group, plays Wednesday in Ottawa against the French, while England will take on the upstart Colombians.

entry.title: England beats Mexico 2-0 at Women's World Cup
entry.summary: Fran Kirby and Karen Carney scored in the second half, and England beat Mexico 2-1 Saturday at the Women's World Cup in Moncton, New Brunswick.

entry.title: Carlos becomes a hurricane over Pacific off southwest Mexico
entry.summary:
MIAMI (AP) - Hurricane Carlos hovered Saturday over the Pacific Ocean south of Acapulco, Mexico, hours after a hurricane watch was issued for a swath of that country's southwest coastline, forecasters said.

Mexico's government has issued a hurricane watch from Lazaro Cardenas to Punta San Telmo along Mexico's southwest mainland coast, meaning hurricane conditions were possible within that area within 48 hours.

entry.title: Dismembered bodies of Russian mom, daughter found at Mexico home; prosecutors suspect relative
entry.summary: TIJUANA, Mexico - Officials in the Mexican border state of Baja California say the dismembered bodies of a 45-year-old Russian woman and her 12-year-old daughter were found in a garage and they suspect a family member.

entry.title: Mexico cheer-dance Nazi routine criticised
entry.summary: A cheer-dance team in Mexico has drawn criticism for a routine in which they displayed flags with swastikas, dressed in pseudo-military outfits and one girl appeared to toss a Nazi salute to the crowd.

entry.title: Girls dance team in Mexico criticised over bizarre 'Nazi dance'
entry.summary: Mexico doesn't have any significant neo-Nazi movements.

entry.title: Mexico supreme court opens door to gay marriage nationwide
Mexico Supreme Court Opens Door to Gay Marriage Nationwide
entry.summary:
Mexico's supreme court has ruled it is unconstitutional for Mexican states to bar same-sex marriages.

Gay marriage is legal in some parts of Mexico, including Mexico City and the northern state of Coahuila.

entry.title: Mexico Supports Probe Into Shooting of US Helicopter
entry.summary: Mexico has long opposed any militarization of the border.

entry.title: Mexico supports probe into shooting of US helicopter
entry.summary:
MEXICO CITY (AP) - The Mexican government says it is working with the United States in the investigation into a shooting attack on a U.S. Customs and Border Protection helicopter on June 5, but says it "categorically rejects any attempt to see the border as a security threat."

Mexico's Foreign Relations Department said Thursday the U.S. border informed the Mexican government that it will send two Blackhawk helicopters to patrol the Texas border area where the helicopter was hit.

entry.title: Tropical storm Carlos forms off Mexico's Pacific coast
entry.summary:
MEXICO CITY Tropical storm Carlos formed off the southern Pacific coast of Mexico on Thursday and was expected to gain some strength in the coming days, the U.S. National Hurricane Center said.

The center said the storm was expected to move in a path northward, parallel to the coast of Mexico and that no watches or warnings were in effect.

entry.title: Mexico says it found offshore oil reserves in Gulf
entry.summary: MEXICO CITY (AP) " Mexico's state-owned oil company says it found four shallow-water offshore oil and gas fields in the Gulf of Mexico with total possible reserves of 350 million barrels of crude equivalent.

entry.title: Mexico decries new Texas law beefing up security on border
Mexico decries new Texas law beefing up security along border, says it will 'promote division'
entry.summary: Mexico's Foreign Relations Department said Wednesday the new law will "promote division between our societies, and runs contrary to the principles and values governing the U.S.-Mexico bilateral relationship."

entry.title: Mexico decries new Texas law beefing up security on border
entry.summary: Mexico didn't appear to object to moves to replace the National Guard troops.

entry.title: Congress considering repeal of meat labeling law
entry.summary: The supporters have called on the U.S. government to negotiate with Canada and Mexico to find labels acceptable to all countries.

entry.title: US Congress considering repeal of meat labeling law
entry.summary:
Canada and Mexico have said they will now ask the WTO for permission to raise tariffs on U.S. goods.

Canada and Mexico have opposed the law because it causes their animals to be segregated from those of U.S. origin " a costly process that has forced some U.S. companies to stop buying exports.

entry.title: Congress considering repeal of meat labeling law in face of retaliation from Canada and Mexico
entry.summary: WASHINGTON -- House Republicans are hoping to repeal a law requiring country-of-origin labels on packages of meat to avoid costly trade retaliation from Canada and Mexico.

entry.title: Mexico' government says teacher testing will go ahead as planned
entry.summary:
MEXICO CITY - The Mexican government says teacher testing will go on as planned, despite the objections of radical teachers' unions.

Many teachers in Mexico's under-performing schools have essentially inherited their posts.

entry.title: Late Colombia goal denies Mexico first World Cup win
entry.summary:
Mexico was the better team dominating possession, grabbing the early lead on a brilliant 36th minute strike from midfielder Veronica Perez.

Ranked 26th in the world, Mexico will play England in its next game, while number 28 Colombia will face France.

entry.title: Montoya's late goal earns Colombia 1-1 draw with Mexico
entry.summary: Daniela Montoya's booming goal from outside the penalty area in the 82nd minute helped Colombia recover for a 1-1 draw against Mexico in the women's World Cup in Moncton, New Brunswick on Tuesday.

entry.title: Mexico soccer probe targets coach Herrera, 2 players over partisan tweets on election day
entry.summary: MEXICO CITY - The Mexican Soccer Federation is investigating national team coach Miguel Herrera and two players over politically tinged tweets sent the day of the country's recent elections.

entry.title: Mexican Soccer probes coach, 2 players over partisan tweets
entry.summary: Peralta, who plays professionally for Club America of Mexico City, sent tweets urging Mexicans to vote using a hash tag that translates as "WearGreen" and was used by others to promote the party.

entry.title: The Latest: New Mexico Legislature OKs bills, adjourns
entry.summary:
A measure to fund state courts and the state Department of Health has cleared the New Mexico Legislature.

The New Mexico House of Representatives has passed a measure to fund state courts and the state Department of Health and a proposal on a bundle of tax incentives.

The New Mexico Senate has passed a bill to fund $295 million worth of public works projects.

The New Mexico Senate has convened in Santa Fe to do its part to iron out a battle over funding $295 million worth of public works projects.

New Mexico lawmakers are heading back to Santa Fe in an effort to resolve partisan bickering over a $295 million capital projects package.

entry.title: Mexico's ruling party close to keeping majority despite violence, graft
entry.summary: Initial estimates from Mexico's electoral authority had the PRI and its partners winning between 246 and 263 lower house seats.

entry.title: Winners and losers: 5 takeaways from Mexico midterm vote
entry.summary:
MEXICO CITY (AP) - Here are five things to know about Mexico's midterm elections, seen as a referendum on President Enrique Pena Nieto's government halfway through his six-year mandate.

His win is a first for Mexico, made possible by a reform last year allowing people not affiliated with parties to run.

entry.title: Mexico President Poised for Majority Despite Discontent
entry.summary:
Under Mexico's mixed system of direct and proportional elections for congressional seats, analysts predicted the PRI coalition will ultimately control 245 to 263 seats in the 500-seat legislature.

The third main political force, the conservative National Action of the Party that produced Mexico's two previous presidents, maintained more or less steady support with about 21 percent of the vote.

The most notable example was the election of Jaime Rodriguez, known as "El Bronco," who became the first independent candidate in Mexico to win a governor's race, in Nuevo Leon state.

entry.title: Officials probe release of felon accused of killing officer
entry.summary: ALBUQUERQUE, N.M. (AP) - New Mexico's attorney general is investigating the circumstances that led to the release of a repeat offender who prosecutors say went on to kill a police officer.

entry.title: Ruling party leads, 1st independent wins in Mexico elections
entry.summary: The biggest loser was the Democratic Revolution Party, which has been Mexico's leading leftist party for a quarter century.
